Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN3_1}Rhesos
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EN3_1}Rhesos sits in a plateau in the Dryatic mountains. Highland cattle thrive on the grasses of the heights.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN3_2}Dyopalis
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN1_4}Dyopalis lies in a valley in the Dryatic mountains. Despite the cold winters, the region's fertile soils make this district one of the breadbaskets of the northern Empire.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN4_1}Gaos
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EN4_1}Gaos sits in a broad valley in the Myzead, the hill country in the east of the empire. Nomadic herders once occupied this land, and the village's name is taken from their word for cattle.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN4_2}Themys
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN5_3}Themys lies under a ridge of limestone crags in the Myzead, the hill country of the imperial heartland. The grasses on the rolling downs are well-suited to the raising of sheep.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN5_1}Atrion
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EN5_1}Atrion in the valley of the Nevys, a cold, slow-moving river that drains into Lake Laconis. The land here is suitable for the cultivation of mulberry bushes, used to produce silk.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN5_2}Masangara
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN2_3}Masangara sits on the banks of the Nevys, a cold, slow-moving river that empties into Lake Laconis. Cattle are raised here in former marshy woodlands, now drained and turned into meadows.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN6_1}Ataconia
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EN6_1}Ataconia sits on a plateau in the piedmont of the Dryatic mountains. The streams rushing down from the mountains have exposed deposits of salt in the hillsides, which are mined by the local population.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN6_2}Potamis
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN4_1}Potamis sits in a valley in the lower Dryatic mountains. The people of these parts have raised cattle since pre-Calradic times, and its milk and butter are sought out by traders and travellers passing through the region.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN7_1}Epinosa
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EN7_1}Epinosa lies in the far north of the Empire, just south of the glacial lakes known as the Iltan portages, where ships are hauled between Lakes Laconis and Tanaesis. The region is relatively thinly populated, but large herds of cattle graze on the green downs.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN7_2}Pons
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EN7_2}Pons is one of the northernmost settlements of the Empire. It is named for the 'crossing' of the Iltan portages, a network of glacial lakes that allow ships to be hauled between Lakes Laconis and Tanaesis. The locals mine deposits of salt in the nearby hills.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN8_1}Syratos
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EN8_1}Syratos sits at the base of an escarpment just north of Lake Tanaesis. Flax grows well here, in the cold damp valley floor.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN8_2}Tememos
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EN8_2}Tememos lies in heavily wooded hill country at the northern end of Lake Tanaesis. Many of the villagers work as foresters, harvesting oak, beech and pine for the sale to the lake cities.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_EN1}Epicrotea
Settlement.text: {=n9WMUuSp}Epicrotea, the 'All-Conquering' was named after the eccentric long-haired military genius Sarapios, who crushed a Battanian host and secured the lands west of Lake Laconis for the Empire. Its towers, overlooking the Miron river, have frequently been a northerner's first glimpse of the awesome and terrible force to their south.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EN1_1}Marathea
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN1_1}Marathea lies on a narrow shelf of land between the Miron river and Mount Aracathos, the tallest peak in the Dryatic mountains. The villagers are skilled miners, extracting iron ores from the nearby cliffside.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EN1_2}Stathymos
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN1_2}Stathymos lies in a narrow valley beneath a towering ridge of the Dryatic mountains. The highland streams wash fertile soil down the hillsides, making this district one of the breadbaskets of the imperial north.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EN1_3}Gymos
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN1_3}Gymos is a quiet fishing village in the Diathmic Bay, on the far west of Lake Laconis. Villagers harvest pike from the bay's deep waters.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_EN2}Diathma
Settlement.text: {=wKMo2CUP}Diathma, the city of the Divine Decree, was erected by an imperial general on the ruins of a Dryatic shrine overlooking Lake Laconis. It was the last stand of the Dryatics, the northernmost of the Palaic peoples, who rebelled against the Empire and were overcome. According to legend they were pushed back into the shallows of the lake and fought until they were exhausted and the bloody waters engulfed them.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EN2_1}Alosea
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN2_1}Alosea lies near the entrance of the Diathmic Bay, on the far western end of Lake Laconis. The folk of this region live well off the pike and sturgeon of the lake.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EN2_2}Jeracos
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN2_2}Jeracos sits in meadowland in the northern piedmont of the Dryatic mountains. The slopes of the nearby hills are pierced with mineshafts. Despite centuries of use, they still yield ores from which silver can be extracted through various cunning techniques.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_EN3}Saneopa
Settlement.text: {=EJZLzhJk}Saneopa sits on a low pass leading from the Nevys valley to the north to the pool of the Ophthys. The ancient Palaic peoples of this region, like the Battanians, treated lakes as sacred sites, and the Ophthys in particular was said to be a gateway to another world. The hustle and bustle of Saneopa, one of the main trading centers of inland Calradia, stands in sharp contrast to the dark and silent waters below.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EN3_1}Enoisa
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN3_1}Enoisa sits by the shores of the Ophthys, the eye, a deep lake in the hill country south of the Dryatic mountains. Wheat grows here, fed by the ample rains of the north. Legend has it that this was once a shrine of the ancient Palaic people, who believed the lake was a gateway to another world.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES1_1}Odrysa
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES1_1}Odrysa lies on the far eastern frontiers of the Empire, just across the River Tiagys from lands that are now the Khuzait Khanate. Though this area is dry, oak and other trees grow in the Tiagys gorges and other nooks in the hills, sustaining a small lumber industry.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES1_2}Caira
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES1_1}Caira sits amid the network of rivers, lakes and lagoons known as the Calsea. Any further east, the land becomes alkaline and barren, but here the floodplains of the parallel Calsa and Tiagys rivers allow the growing of wheat.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES2_1}Corenia
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES2_1}Corenia is one of the farthest flung villages of the empire to speak the Calradic tongue. It sits in the plains southeast of Lake Tanaesis in the shadow of the Akkan Hills, beyond which is spoken only Darshi and the languages of the steppe. Villagers grow grain here, keeping watch for raiders from across the frontiers.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES2_2}Metachia
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES2_2}Metachia is the lies on the southern shores of Lake Tanaesis in the frontier lands beyond River Tiagys. This imperial colony, established in more peaceful times, is a center for mulberry bushes used in silk production.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES3_1}Melion
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES3_1}Melion in a narrow valley near the center of the Myzead, a rugged plateau in the east of the Empire. Villagers here cultivate mulberry bushes. The leaves are harvested and fed to silkworks, producing thread much valued by both refined imperial nobles for their courtwear and hard-riding nomads and frontiersmen, who wear it beneath their armor as an extra layer of protection against arrows.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES3_2}Sagolina
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES3_2}Sagolina sits at the foot of a narrow valley in the Myzead, a rugged plateau in eastern Calradia. The silver mined from nearby hills helps explain the effort and expense to which the Empire has gone in past centuries to conquer and defend these lands.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES4_1}Lavenia
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES4_1}Lavenia is a fishing village on the northeastern shores of the Perassic Sea. The nearby castle guards one of the main passages over the network of lakes and salt lagoons known as the Calsea, one of the gateways to Aserai lands.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES4_2}Ethemisa
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES4_2}Ethemisa sits on the river that the Aserai call the Nahr al-Kals, the Bitter River, and what imperial citizens call the Calsa. Here, the river has just descended from the coastal hills and has not yet reached the alkali plains of the southeast. The lands around produce a fine crop of grain.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES5_1}Morenia
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES5_1}Morenia sits overlooking the Sethys river, on a low pass leading over the hills to the valley of the Lycarea. Villagers collect clay from the riverbanks for the kilns of the imperial southlands.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES5_2}Atphynia
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES2_1}The village of Atphynia sits near the mouth of the Sethys river, just before it splits into three to form the valley known as Tripotamia. Villagers here have laid out salt pans near where the Sethys estuary joins the Perassic sea.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES6_1}Sestadaim
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES6_1}Sestadaim sits on the western side of the great Ornian rock, an outcrop in the center of the Lycarea valley. Some say the vultures for which the rock is named once gathered here to feast on the bodies of those who died working the local salt mines.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES6_2}Amycon
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES6_3}Amycon lies in a series of small but sharp ridges between the Ornion Rock and the Aris valley. The people of this land are sheep herders, known for their dry, salty cheese flavored with cumin.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES7_1}Jogurys
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES7_1}Jogurys lies on the flat western shores of Lake Tanaesis. This land was originally inhabited by nomadic tribes and has come under cultivation only recently. Imperial colonists have made intensive efforts to grow mullberry bushes here to raise silkworms, a lucrative product in this region.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES7_2}Eunalica
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES7_3}Eunalica sits on the western shores of Lake Tanaesis. This low-lying country is fine land for the growing of flax.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES8_1}Chanopsis
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES8_1}Chanopsis sits near the headwaters of the Sethys river in the plateau region known as the Myzead. Wheat grows well on the sun-baked plains.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES8_2}Popsia
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES4_2}Popsia in a narrow canyon between the Ornian Rock and the valley of the Ophthys pool. Trees grow tall here in the cool shadows of the hills, and villagers harvest pines for sale as lumber.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_ES1}Danustica
Settlement.text: {=xkkI7ejQ}The frontier city of Danustica dominates the network of lakes and lagoons known as the Calsea. It has long held the line against incursions by the Aserai and various Darshi shahs and padishahs further to the east. Many an imperial legionary stationed here has scribbled graffiti on its walls cursing the city's sweltering summers, brackish water and the mosquitos that rise from the Calsea, but the inhabitants are proud of their role as border defenders and mock the soldiers wilting in the heat around them.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES1_2}Polisia
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES1_2}Polisia sits among the network of rivers and lakes known as the Calsea near the Aserai borderlands. Villagers harvest salt from a lagoon to their west, a former inlet of the Perassic sea that was cut off by a sandspit. These lowlands are shunned by many others in Calradia, who find the air thick and fetid, but the inhabitants are proud of their role keeping watch on the Aserai.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES1_3}Tegresos
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES1_3}Tegresos sits just north of the River Calsa, right before it enters the network of lakes, creeks and lagoons that form the borderlands with the Aserai. The inhabitants of this region have bred sheep that feed on marsh-grasses.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES1_4}Erebulos
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES1_4}Erebulos lies by a lagoon that was formerly part of the Perassic Sea, closed by a recently formed sandspit. Villagers scoop clay from the creek-bottoms here, selling it to the pottery kilns of Danustica and other nearby towns.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_ES2}Vostrum
Settlement.text: {=ytBRXqt8}Vostrum was founded by the Calradian mercenary Archacos, one of a number of rogue commanders who broke away from the empire during its expansion. Unlike some, who tried to reproduce the empire's republican heritage, he chose to rule as a god-king. His dynasty lasted for generations, until imperial troops overran it and smashed every haloed statue of Archacos and his successors into rubble. Even today, western and northern imperial senators accuse families from this region of being closet monarchists.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES2_2}Gorcorys
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES2_2}Gorcorys sits on the Gorea, the southernmost tributary of the Sethys river in the valley of Tripotamia. The dark, well-watered soil here makes this region an imperial breadbasket.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES2_3}Avalyps
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES2_3}Avalyps sits near the headwaters of the River Calsa in the warm coastal hills of the southern Empire. The dark, well-watered soil here makes this region an imperial breadbasket.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_ES3}Poros
Settlement.text: {=rGXdJybe}The town of Poros sits near the northern shores of the Perassic Sea. The warm rolling hills of these parts are well suited to the raising of sheep and horses. The herdsmen have a reputation for being proud and violent, but the nobles of the Leonipardes clan who rule this land are careful to respect their autonomy. Livestock rustling and blood feuds are common here, and it is said that the Leonipardes will never interfere unless invited by both parties, but when they do, their judgments will be obeyed by all.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES3_1}Canoros
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES3_1}Canoros sits in the flat southern reaches of the Lycarea plain. This land has been good horse country since even before the Empire came, furnishing the steeds of the Lycarean riders who routed several Calradian armies before their final defeat and absorption into the imperial cavalry.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES3_2}Tevea
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES3_2}Tevea sits where the plains of Lycarea slowly ascend to meet the base of the Ornian Rock, named for the vultures who perch on its crags to keep watch on the hazy plains below. Depressions lying in the shadow of the rock remain wet for most of the year, making for good land in which to grow flax.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_ES4}Lycaron
Settlement.text: {=WGtzBswe}The natural fortress of Lycaron sits on a spur jutting out of the great Ornian rock. In the final years of the imperial conquest, the Palaic tribe here negotiated a peaceful federation with the empire, only to see their home seized by the rebel leader Gethuz. The ensuing siege was only the first of many that Lycaron would undergo in the ensuing centuries, as its nearby silver mines made it a prize for every imperial pretender who ever tried to seize power in a civil war. It is said that the colony of vultures who inhabit the upper reaches of the Rock have dined on the flesh of every people of Calradia.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES4_1}Sagora
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES4_1}Sagora sits on a low ridge in the middle of the Lycarean plain. This district is one of the rockier and less fertile parts of the plain, but the valley scrub still supports the grazing of sheep.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES4_3}Canterion
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES4_3}Canterion lies in the east of the Lycarean plain. The slowly rising land here gets more rain than other parts of the plain, and the rich grasses have made it good horse country since even before the coming of the Empire.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_ES5}Onira
Settlement.text: {=4ENGzVaC}The tale of Sarpea of Onira is one of the epic poems of the eastern frontier. Like many, it seems written to justify the Empire's conquest. Sarpea, a senator's daughter, was seized by a Palaic chieftain and carried to his citadel here. When the imperial armies appeared before its walls years later to rescue her, she begged them to retreat for the sake of her infant son, whom her fearsome husband had threatened to hurl from the walls instead of allowing him to be captured and raised by his mother's people. The legions withdrew, so the story says, but the boy grew into a warrior who joined the Empire and slew his father. It is now the center of a horse-breeding industry on the eastern plains.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES5_1}Lanthas
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES5_1}Lanthas lies in the broad plains south of Lake Tanaesis. This is good sheep country, but in a land scoured by imperial fugitives, wild Eleftheroi riders and steppe nomads, the villagers here have learned to watch their flocks closely.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES5_2}Lartusys
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES5_2}Lartusys lies near the southern end of Lake Tanaesis. The village sits near a deposit of salt, and salt springs occasionally bubble to the surface, feeding the legend that this was once a gateway to a haunted underground sea.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES5_3}Parasemnos
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES5_3}Parasemnos sits in a low pass linking the Tanaeitic plain with the valley of the Calsa river. The villagers mine salt from deposits beneath the ridges on the Calsean side of the pass.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_ES6}Phycaon
Settlement.text: {=RL2vacqv}Phycaon sits at the head of the Sethys valley, one of the main grain-producing regions of the central Empire. Once the largest of the Palaic cities, its leaders led a league of the tribes against imperial encroachment into the region. But when the empire's victory looked inevitable, they made their peace. The population, now thoroughly Calradicized, have a reputation for being serious, respectable and trade-minded, dependable if a bit humorless.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES6_1}Saldannis
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES6_1}Saldannis lies beneath gypsum bluffs overlooking the River Sethys. The fine soil of the hills makes for a sticky clay when it washes down to the river, much prized by the potters of the imperial south.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES6_2}Spotia
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES6_2}Spotia lies alongside the gently flowing Sethys river. The low rolling hills of this district comprise one of the breadbaskets of the Empire.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EW6_2}Sardol
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW1_3}Nideon sits on a low-lying meander of the Zeos river, in the shadow of the plutonic Mount Erithrys. Wine grapes grow on the gentle slopes rising up from the river valley.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EW9_2}East Landing
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW1_3}Nideon sits on a low-lying meander of the Zeos river, in the shadow of the plutonic Mount Erithrys. Wine grapes grow on the gentle slopes rising up from the river valley.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_EW1}Minas Tirith
Settlement.text: {==Settlements.Settlement.text.town_EW1}The Tower of Guard, Gondor's capital and greatest fortress-city, built in seven concentric levels on the Hill of Guard at the eastern end of the White Mountains with Mount Mindolluin behind it. The White City houses the Citadel with the Tower of Ecthelion, the Court of the Fountain with the White Tree, and serves as seat of the Stewards of Gondor (and later King Elessar). Surrounded by the fertile Pelennor Fields enclosed by the great defensive wall called the Rammas Echor.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW1_1}North Pelennor Fields
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW1_1}A Gondor village

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW1_2}Anorien Village
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW1_2}A Gondor village.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW1_3}South Pelennor Fields
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW1_3}A Gondor village.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_EW2}West Osgiliath
Settlement.text: {==Settlements.Settlement.text.town_EW2}The western ruins of the ancient capital on the Anorien bank of the Anduin, held by Gondorian forces as a forward defensive position despite being mostly abandoned after the Great Plague. The western side of the shattered bridge connects to a causeway leading toward Minas Tirith, with Rangers maintaining a garrison among the ruins to prevent Mordor from using the crossing. Haunted by memories of former glory when it was Gondor's greatest city for over a thousand years.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW2_2}North Pelennor
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW2_2}A Gondor village

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW2_3}Pelennor Village
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW2_3}A Gondor village.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW2_4}South Pelennor
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW2_4}A Gondor village.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_EW3}East Osgliath
Settlement.text: {==Settlements.Settlement.text.town_EW3}The eastern ruins of Gondor's ancient capital across the Anduin from West Osgiliath, now a haunted battlefield contested between Gondor's Rangers and Mordor's forces. The broken eastern half of the great bridge leads to collapsed buildings and flooded streets where Orcs lurk among fallen towers. Strategic crossing point controlling access to Ithilien and the road to Minas Morgul.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW3_2}Henneth Annûn
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW3_2}Hidden Ranger outpost

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW3_4}North Ithilien Village
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW3_4}A Gondorian Village

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_EW4}Pelargir
Settlement.text: {==Settlements.Settlement.text.town_EW4}Pelargir stands at the confluence of the River Sirith and the Great River Anduin in the heart of Lebennin. The city occupies both banks of the Sirith where it joins the Anduin, approximately 100 miles upriver from the Mouths of Anduin (Ethir Anduin) where the Great River empties into the Bay of Belfalas, and roughly 126 miles downriver from the ruins of Osgiliath and the approach to Minas Tirith. This positioning grants Pelargir extraordinary strategic value. The Anduin here flows wide, deep, and calm - ideal for large ships and extensive port facilities. The city serves as the nexus point between Gondor's inland territories and the sea, where goods from Minas Tirith, Lossarnach, and the northern provinces meet cargo from coastal regions and distant ports. More crucially, Pelargir functions as the gateway controlling access to Gondor's heartland via the Great River - any fleet moving up the Anduin to threaten Minas Tirith must pass through or bypass Pelargir's waters.When first founded in the Second Age, Pelargir stood mere miles from the coast of the Bay of Belfalas. However, after the catastrophic Downfall of Númenor reshaped the world's geography, the coastline retreated dramatically westward and southward, leaving Pelargir far inland at the head of what became the Anduin's extensive delta region. This geographical transformation actually enhanced the city's security - Corsair raiders could no longer strike directly from the sea but had to navigate the treacherous channels of the Ethir Anduin or sail far upriver to reach the city, giving defenders time to prepare and respond.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW4_1}Ost Anglebed
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW4_1}Ost Anglebedserves as both a substantial town and the guardian station for Amon Anglebed, one of Gondor's crucial warning beacons. The settlement sits in good agricultural land with access to one of the Five Rivers of Lebennin, making it prosperous from both farming and its strategic position on roads connecting Pelargir to other regions.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW4_3}Tumladen
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW4_3}Tumladen served as refuge for civilians fleeing the Corsair occupation of Pelargir.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW4_4}Linhir
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW4_4}Linhir stands as a substantial city that spans both banks of the River Gilrain, one of the Five Rivers of Lebennin. Though technically the city belongs to the principality of Dor-en-Ernil (the lands ruled by the Prince of Dol Amroth), it maintains close connections with Lebennin and serves as a major crossing point between the western coastal regions and the Anduin valley.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_EW5}Dol Amroth
Settlement.text: {==Settlements.Settlement.text.town_EW5}Dol Amroth stands as a fortress-city upon a high promontory jutting westward into the Bay of Belfalas, commanding Gondor's southern coast with majestic authority. The city occupies the southern end of the small bay called Cobas Haven, where the River Ringló flows into the sea. This peninsula position grants Dol Amroth natural defensive advantages - towering cliffs protect seaward approaches, while massive walls guard the landward sides. The city's elevated position allows watchers on the Sea-ward Tower to scan vast stretches of ocean for approaching ships, whether friendly traders or hostile Corsair raiders.The name commemorates a tragic love story from the distant past. In T.A. 1981, Amroth, the last King of Lórien, came to Edhellond (the Elven haven fifty miles north) seeking passage to Aman with his beloved Nimrodel. She had fled Lórien's darkness after the Balrog awakened in Moria, and Amroth had promised to follow her into the West. But Nimrodel became lost in the White Mountains, never reaching the coast. Amroth waited aboard the last ship from Edhellond, but when a great autumn storm drove the vessel out to sea, he leaped overboard in a desperate attempt to swim ashore and search for her. He drowned in the bay's cold waters, and Nimrodel was never found. The hill where the Princes' stronghold stood was thereafter called Dol Amroth in memory of the lost Elf-king's final moments - a poignant reminder that even immortal beings can fall to grief and the sea's merciless power.The principality itself is known by multiple names. Officially, the fief is called Belfalas, or alternatively Dor-en-Ernil, reflecting its unique status as a hereditary princedom within the kingdom of Gondor. In the Common Speech, the region is sometimes called the Langstrand, though this name more properly belongs to Anfalas to the west.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW5_1}Melgobas
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW5_1}A Gondorian fisherman village.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW5_2}Ost Lontir
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW5_2}A Gondorian Village.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW5_3}Tadrent
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW5_3}A Gondorian Village.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_EW6}Lond Cirion
Settlement.text: {==Settlements.Settlement.text.town_EW6}Lond Cirion stands at the mouth of the mighty River Lagorduin where it empties into the Bay of Belfalas, commanding the central coastline of Anfalas - the Long Beach, also known as Langstrand in the Common Speech. The city holds the unique distinction of being the oldest Númenórean settlement in all of Gondor, predating even the great cities of Pelargir and Minas Anor, founded by the first wave of Númenórean seafarers who discovered the Bay of Belfalas during the Second Age.Originally named Ciryalondë by those ancient mariners, the settlement served as the first permanent foothold of Númenor on the mainland of Middle-earth in this region. Over the millennia, as the Quenya tongue faded from common use and Sindarin became the primary Elvish language of Gondor, the old name fell from memory and was replaced by Lond Cirion. The current name honors Cirion, the twelfth Ruling Steward of Gondor (T.A. 2489-2567), who forged the legendary alliance with the Éothéod that led to the founding of Rohan - though whether the city was renamed during his lifetime or posthumously to commemorate his deeds remains uncertain in historical records.The city rises in dramatic terraces up from the harbor, built into the rocky hillsides that characterize this stretch of coastline. Ancient Númenórean engineering is evident in the massive retaining walls and stone foundations that support the upper levels, testament to the skill of builders who worked here over four thousand years ago. The city's multi-level construction allows it to maximize defensibility while maintaining access to the vital harbor below, with ingenious lift systems connecting the upper, middle, and lower districts.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW6_1}Melgobas
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW6_1}A Gondorian fisherman village.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW6_3}Sadrech
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW6_3}A Gondorian Village.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW6_4}Barad Faen
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW6_4}A Gondorian Village.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_EW7}Bar Melui
Settlement.text: {==Settlements.Settlement.text.town_EW7}Arnach serves as the traditional seat and stronghold of Lord Forlong, though the corpulent lord maintains closer personal ties to Imloth Melui through his marriage to Lady Vanyalos. The town represents the administrative and military center of Lossarnach, where taxes are collected, justice dispensed, and the fiefdom's military forces mustered.The settlement takes its name from the ancient pre-Númenórean kingdom of Arnach that once controlled these valleys, preserving a connection to peoples who lived here millennia before Gondor's founding. This antiquity shows in the town's layout - irregular streets following ancient pathways rather than the ordered planning typical of Númenórean cities, and foundations incorporating stonework whose origins are lost to time.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW7_1}Ost Norhir
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW7_1}A small fortified village..

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW7_2}Ritherstad
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW7_2}A Gondorian Village.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW7_3}Bergraw
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW7_3}A Gondorian Village.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_EW8}Ost Arndir
Settlement.text: {==Settlements.Settlement.text.town_EW8}Ost Arndir is the primary stronghold and seat of power in Pinnath Gelin, one of the fertile green hill-lands of southern Gondor. The fortress serves as the capital settlement of this important agricultural region, which functions as a breadbasket for the kingdom.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW8_1}Iáphel
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW8_1}Iáphel is renowned throughout Gondor as home to some of the finest vineyards in all the Southlands. The village's terraced hillside vineyards benefit from the maritime climate near the Bay of Belfalas, producing wines that have long graced the tables of the Stewards of Gondor and now King Elessar himself. The vintages of Iáphel are so exceptional that even Elves are rumored to favor them over wines crafted by their own kin, though none would openly admit such preference. The village consists of winemakers' estates, pressing houses, storage cellars carved into the hillsides, and a small market square where traders from Dol Amroth and Pelargir come to purchase casks. The wealth from wine trade has made Iáphel's stone buildings more refined than typical farming villages, with decorative archways and well-maintained walls.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW8_2}Cressfeld
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW8_2}Situated at the confluence of waters, Cressfeld serves as a breadbasket village whose farmers toil to supply their neighbors with essential foodstuffs. The rich alluvial soil deposited by the meeting rivers makes the surrounding fields exceptionally fertile for grain, vegetables, and orchards. Summer crops flourish here - the village is particularly known for its abundance of fresh produce during the growing season. Cressfeld features modest timber-and-stone farmhouses clustered near a central grain mill powered by the river current, with fields radiating outward in a patchwork of cultivation. A small ford allows crossing of the Lagorduin, making Cressfeld a minor waypoint for travelers moving between the coastal settlements and the interior hill country. The village maintains close ties with Ost Arndir, providing regular shipments of food to feed the fortress garrison and the craftsmen of the regional capital.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW8_3}Cornworth
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW8_3}Cornworth sprawls across gentle hillsides blanketed with golden wheat fields that wave like a harvest sea when the wind blows from the bay. The village specializes in cultivating the hearty wheat varieties that thrive in Pinnath Gelin's temperate climate, producing grain of such quality that the bakers of Ost Arndir credit all excellence in their breads to Cornworth's harvest. The settlement centers around several large threshing barns and granary buildings where the wheat is processed and stored before transport. Even in the humility typical of farming folk, Cornworth's farmers take quiet pride in knowing that their grain sustains much of the surrounding region. The village architecture is functional and sturdy - stone foundations with timber upper stories and thatched roofs, built to last generations. During harvest season, Cornworth swells with temporary workers from neighboring villages, and the communal celebration of harvest's end is considered one of the finest festivals in all of Pinnath Gelin.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_EW9}Calembel
Settlement.text: {==Settlements.Settlement.text.town_EW9}Calembel stands as the principal town of Lamedon, commanding a small but prominent hill overlooking the fords of the River Ciril in northern Gondor. The town's position makes it a critical waypoint on the ancient road connecting Erech in the Morthond Vale to the great port city of Pelargir, serving as both guardian of the river crossing and gateway between the mountainous interior and the fertile lowlands of southern Gondor. The Ciril's fords below the town represent one of the few reliable crossing points in the region, and control of Calembel has historically meant control of movement through western Lamedon.The town rises in terraced levels up the hillside, with the imposing castle of Angbor - Lord of Lamedon - crowning the summit. From this vantage, watchmen can observe traffic on the road for miles in either direction and monitor the river valleys where tributaries descend from the White Mountains to the north. The elevation also provides natural defensive advantages, though Calembel has long been more administrative center than fortress, its strength lying in the loyalty of Lamedon's people rather than impregnable walls.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW9_1}Bar Elir
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW9_1}Bar Elir enjoys a reputation throughout Lamedon for possessing the most fertile soil in the entire fiefdom - a gift of the converging rivers that annually deposit rich sediment across the surrounding fields. The farmstead sprawls across the river junction with numerous homesteads, grain storage barns, and water-powered mills taking advantage of the strong currents where the two waterways meet. Unlike the sheep-focused settlements of northern Lamedon, Bar Elir specializes in intensive agriculture: wheat, barley, vegetables, and orchards that supply Calembel and contribute to the food stores of Dol Amroth. The rivers also provide abundant freshwater fish, particularly prized in coastal cities where Bar Elir's fishermen trade their catches. During planting and harvest seasons, the population swells with temporary laborers from less fertile areas, creating a lively atmosphere uncommon in the usually sedate countryside. The confluence itself is marked by an ancient stone bridge - possibly of Númenórean construction - that carries the eastern road toward Pelargir. The prosperity brought by fertile land has made Bar Elir's buildings more substantial than typical farmsteads, with several manorial estates belonging to wealthy landholder families who pledge allegiance to Lord Angbor in Calembel.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW9_2}Lothgobel
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW9_2}Lothgobel stands as a modest but resilient village on the main northern route into Lamedon, positioned where travelers descending from the mountain passes first glimpse the fertile valleys below. The settlement consists of sturdy stone-and-timber buildings characteristic of upland Gondorian construction, with steep-pitched roofs to shed mountain rains and thick walls against winter winds from the White Mountains. During the War of the Ring, Lothgobel suffered occupation by Corsairs of Umbar who used its strategic position to threaten the road to Calembel, forcing many inhabitants to flee to their lord's stronghold. The village's central tavern - a significant structure for such a small settlement - serves as gathering place for travelers and locals alike, offering respite before the final approach to the regional capital. Following liberation by Aragorn and the Army of the Dead, Lothgobel's people have returned to rebuild their lives, though the memory of occupation lingers in cautious glances toward the southern roads. The surrounding hillsides support small farms and pastures where sheep graze, contributing to Lamedon's reputation as a center for wool production.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW9_3}Dínadab
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW9_3}Dínadab epitomizes the quiet, enduring character of Lamedon's hill-folk. This small hamlet nestles among rolling slopes where shepherds have tended their flocks for generations, living lives largely unchanged since before Númenor's founding. The settlement is so peaceful that even during the tumult of war, it remained a place of relative safety - though not without cost. The hamlet lost Fuirion, one of its sons, during the Dawnless Day when Sauron's shadow fell across Gondor, and his absence haunts the close-knit community like a wound that won't fully heal. Dínadab's buildings cluster around a central sheepfold and washing pools where the famous Lamedon wool is cleaned in the cold, clear waters flowing down from the mountains. The people here speak with linguistic peculiarities inherited from the ancient Daen folk who inhabited these valleys in ages past, preserving fragments of a culture that existed before Gondor's kings ever looked westward. The hamlet serves as a watch-point for the northern approaches, with riders ready to carry warning to Calembel should danger threaten from the mountain passes.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A1_1}Tubilis
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A1_1}Tubilis lies on the Bay of Charas, which the Aserai call Shariz. Villagers go fishing here amid the offshore islands in search of tuna, sardines, and shark.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A1_2}Fanab
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A1_3}Fanab sits in a low promontory between the bay that the Aserai call the Gulf of Shariz and the inner sea of the Bahr al-Yeshm. The seawinds bring just enough rain to support the cultivation of olive trees.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A2_2}Asmait
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_2}Asmait lies in a nook of the Jabal Ashabi mountains, bordered to the south by the deep desert. Villagers trap floods running down the hills during rare rainstorms, using the water to grow date palms and other crops.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A3_1}Ain Baliq
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A3_1}Ain Baliq is clustered around a well in a wide valley that separates the Jarjara Escarpment from the Jabal Tamar mountains to the west. The surrounding lands, though dry, produce enough grass in the spring to allow the breeding of horses.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A3_2}Deir Hawa
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A3_2}Deir Hawa sits on the windswept southern shores of the sea that the Aserai call the Bahr al-Yeshm. It survives on pit-mining in the dry nearby hills for silver. Although centuries of exploitation have long exhausted the richest veins, the villagers practice a number of close-guarded techniques to extract the precious metal from ore.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A4_1}Medeni
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A4_1}Medeni sits in lowlands between the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and the Jarjara Escarpment. Villagers grow dates by the coast in gardens watered by wells and small dams in the wadis that trap run-off from the cliffs during the short rainy season.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A4_2}Qidnar
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A4_2}Qidnar lies in the floodplain of the Damar river, the most densely populated part of the Aserai lands, where it slices through the Jarjara Escarpment. Farmers here grow date orchards in the rich silt brought by the river's annual flooding.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A5_1}Jamayeh
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A5_1}Jamayeh sits on the southern shores of the sea that the Aserai call the Bahr al Yeshm, the Jade Sea. The climate is well-suited to olive trees that thrive despite the short rainy season.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A5_2}Hunab
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A3_2}Hunab lies in one of the wadis that cut beneath the weathered mesas of the Jarjara Escarpment. Villagers raise horses here, taking advantage of the brief but lush crop of grass that covers the slopes in the spring.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A6_1}Shibal Zumr
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A6_1}Shibal Zumr sits on the Nahr al-Kals, the river of lime. Here the waters are pure and the soil is fertile, and grain is grown. But a short distance to the south, the land becomes barren and alkaline, and only the hardiest crops survive.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A6_2}Lamesa
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A2_1}Lamesa sits amid open plains and patches of dry acacia forest on the eastern shores of the Bahr al-Yeshm. Some of the Aserai's most prized horses graze on the grasses of this district.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A7_1}Uqba
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A7_1}Uqba sits alongside the Perassic Sea. Villagers trap rainwater and runoff from the hills to water their fields and their gardens of date-palms.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A7_2}Bunqaz
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A7_2}Bunqaz sits at the mouth of the great wadi that divides the Jarjara Escarpment from the Jabal Tamar hills. Villagers sink wells here to tap the wadi's groundwater, using it to irrigate their olive groves.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A8_1}Tamnuh
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A8_1}Tamnuh sits near a large lagoon, cut off from the Perassic Sea by a sandspit. Villagers scrape clay from the shallow waters to sell to the region's potters.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A8_2}Kuqa
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A4_3}Kuqa sits at the foot of a range of low hills east of the Bahr al-Yeshm sea, where the Aserai deserts give way to desert-steppe with scattered acacia and scrub. The villagers here sink wells to water their groves of date palms.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A9_1}Barihal
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A9_1}The oasis-village of Barihal sits in a wadi amid the mesas of the Jarjara Escarpment. The land is best known for the horses that are grazed on the desert's short-lived but rich spring grasses.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A9_2}Wadar
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A7_1}Wadar sits in the rocky wadis at the inland edge of the Jarjara Escarpment, before it gives way to barren gravel plains and dunes. Clouds from the Bahr al-Yeshm drop their last reserves of water here in the spring and winter, giving the land just enough grass to support horse-rearing.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_A1}Quyaz
Settlement.text: {=1ImuW3My}Quyaz was once a mercantile republic that dominated the trade between the western ocean and the Perassic Sea, speaking the now all-but-extinct Kannic tongue, a relative of Nahasawi. But imperial hegemony slowly snuffed out its trade, and the rulers was taken over by mercenaries from the Nahasa. It came intermittently under imperial subjugation but today is a prized holding of the Banu Hulyan, a leading clan of the Aserai sultanate.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A1_1}Tasheba
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A1_1}Tasheba lies on the western edges of the Bahr al-Yeshm. Fishermen venture out into the protected waters, gentle and calm for most of the year, for tuna and sardines.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A1_2}Baq
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A1_2}Baq slightly inland from the Bahr al-Yeshm sea, beneath the great granite outcrop of the Jabal Tamar. The seawinds bring the uplands here just enough rain to support the cultivation of olive trees.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A1_4}Hiblet
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A1_4}Hiblet sits at the base of the granite outcrop known as the Jabal Tamar. Rainwater trapped in cracks in the rock is diverted to the village's date-palm gardens.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_A2}Husn Fulq
Settlement.text: {=bnl7Va4c}Husn Fulq sits at the southeastern edge of the Caldea, the network of rivers and brackish lagoons linking the Empire to the Aserai lands. Fulq, also known as Phalcos, was a dark-faced mercenary chieftain who came from lands far to the south. He founded a fortress here and then parlayed its strategic location into a fortune, taking bribes from the Empire and then from the Aserai to switch sides. After 20 years of playing both sides back and forth he sailed home in a ship laden with gold, but many clans of the Aserai proudly claim descent from him, and the 'Tricks of Fulq' are a staple of many a bazaar storyteller's repetoire.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A2_2}Abu Khih
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A2_2}Abu Khih sits along the Nahr al-Kals river on its way to its barren southern reaches. The surrounding lands, an ancient lakebed, are already becoming barren and alkaline, although date-palms still thrive.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A2_3}Hoqqa
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A2_3}Hoqqa sits on the far east of the Aserai lands, on the Tiyagis river. The land is mostly desert-steppe. Barren most of the year except for scrub, it is covered in grass and flowers in the spring and is fine grazing for horses.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_A3}Iyakis
Settlement.text: {=NFIYqaab}Iyakis sits in a cleft in the Jarjara escarpment, where the waters of the fierce but brief desert rains can be trapped and used for irrigation. For generations ago it was an autonomous outpost of the Empire known as Yachios, dominated by the Carasios clan. Fifty years ago however they saw the writing on the wall for imperial dominion in the southlands, and began intermarrying themselves with the tribes of the Nahasa. Today, known as the Qaraz, they take their places in the councils of the sultanate like any other family of the Aserai.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A3_1}Abba
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A3_1}Abba sits on the edge of the deep desert, at the foot of the landward side of the Jarjara Escarpment. Runoff from the hills is trapped underground here, creating springs that sustain an oasis. Wheat thrives in the fields and gardens.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A3_3}Bir Seif
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A3_3}Bir Seif is centered around a group of wells and pools in the Jarjara Escarpment. Villagers dig down to the shallow groundwater layer for clay to sell to the potters of the Nahasa.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_A4}Razih
Settlement.text: {=jXBnf2hQ}Razih is said to be the base from which Kannic explorers set forth to colonize the shores of the Perassic Sea in the centuries before the coming of the empire, the prows of their ships decorated with the intertwined vine leaves of the Kannic goddess of wealth, wine, love and war. Today, the Kannic tongue has been replaced by Nahasawi dialects and their religion is all but forgotten, but the symbol lives on, said to protect those who risk all for the sake of gain or glory.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A4_1}Qablab
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A4_1}Qablab sits near a broad bay on the southern coast of the Perassic Sea. The low-lying coastline is well-suited to the construction of salt pans.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A4_2}Mussum
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A4_2}Mussum sits near the eastern coast of the Bahr al-Yeshm sea, where the Aserai deserts give way to desert-steppe with scattered acacia and scrub. The villagers here sink wells to water their groves of date palms.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A4_4}Doqa
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A4_4}Doqa is a fishing village on the Bahr al-Yeshm sea. Villagers sail out in feluccas to harvest perch that sometimes grow as long as a man is tall, keeping an eye out for the salt-water crocodiles which live in the local inlets and marshes and which compete with them for their catch.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_A5}Hubyar
Settlement.text: {=IIMWPVhU}The inland city of Hubyar is said to be built on the ruins of a luxurious hunting lodge built by the decadent and cruel king Thuran, whom the patriarch Asera slew in vengeance for the enslavement of his family. This memory may explain the worldview of the fierce and austere Banu Qild, who hold the castle today and who detest all frivolity. But the scent of jasmine that can be detected on the night breezes here carries an undercurrent of temptation. It was here that the hero Nimr came to grief, caught in the chamber of a Banu Qild maiden and left hanging in a cage in the market until he perished.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A5_1}Mahloul
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A5_1}Mahloul sits in a broad valley between the Jarjara Escarpment and the Jabal Ashab hills in the desert steppe southeast of the Bahr al-Yeshm. Groundwater provides just enough water to grow crops for subsistence, while the village makes its money from rearing horses on the rich grass that grows in the Jabal Ashabi after the spring rains.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A5_3}Waltas
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A5_3}Waltas sits by the Bahr al-Yeshm, the Jade Sea, in lowlands well suited to the growing of flax.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_A6}Sanala
Settlement.text: {=uO4dxCl8}The port of Sanala is the gateway through which the grain of the lower Damar has flowed forth to feed a hungry world. The Empire's periodic advances south of the Perassic Sea have usually been aimed at seizing this strategic prize. Although the legions were long ago forced to retreat, Sanala remains among the most cosmopolitan cities in Calradia, filled with merchants from many lands bidding for the lowest bulk prices.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A6_1}Mijayit
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A6_1}Mijayit lies off of the estuary of the Damar river as it reaches the Bahr al-Yeshm sea. The rich silt deposits left by the river make this one of the most fertile regions of the Aserai lands.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A6_2}Hamoshawat
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A6_2}Hamoshawat lies on the lower Damar river, just before it reaches the Bahr al-Yeshm sea. The rich silt deposits left by the river make this one of the most fertile regions of the Aserai lands.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A6_3}Jahasim
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A6_3}Jahasim sits on the southern shore of the sea that the Aserai call the Bahr al-Yeshm. The warm waters abound in tuna, bonito, sardines, and other fish.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A6_4}Nahlan
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A6_4}Nahlan sits on the floodplain of the Damar River as it cuts through the Jarjara escarpment. This soil, refreshed yearly by the silt of the flooding river, produces bountiful crops of wheat.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_A7}Askar
Settlement.text: {=GChIoZdd}Askar dominates the middle stretches of the Damar River, as it weaves between the bluffs of the Jarjara Escarpment. This region has been thickly populated for thousands of years, but the river is restless, and every few centuries leaps its banks and erases what comes before. This latest regional capital was an imperial encampment during their furthest penetration of the Nahasa several centuries ago, taken over by the Aserai tribes after the legions withdrew.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A7_2}Bait Hatif
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A7_2}Bait Hatif sits in the floodplain of the Damar river as it cuts through the Jarjara Escarpment. Rocky soil in this district limits irrigation, but horses thrive on the spring grasses of the hills.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A7_3}Mabwaz
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A7_3}Mabwaz overlooks the Damar River as it weaves through the mesas of the Jarjara Escarpment. Villagers grow wheat and other crops in the silt of the river floodplain.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A7_4}Zalm
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A7_4}Zalm sits at the Scorched Gates, where the Damar river descends from the Nahasa desert and starts its journey through the Jarjara Escarpment. The silt brought by the river produces bountiful crops of wheat.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_A8}Qasira
Settlement.text: {=J4bgNT0r}The legendary Queen Eshora, it is said, punished the jinn who were harassing her people by imprisoning them in one of the caves above Qasira, carving the mystical eight-pointed star into the rock to seal them in. She sentenced them to haul water from the depths of the earth, feeding the springs that gush forth from the rocks and which for centuries have irrigated the date gardens of Qasira and its surrounding villages.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A8_1}Ezbet Nahul
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A8_1}Ezbet Nahul sits on a rocky shelf overlooking the waters that the Aserai call the Bahr al-Yeshm, the Jade Sea. Groundwater trapped by the rocks is accessed by wells and used to irrigate the village wheatfields.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A8_2}Abghan
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A8_2}Abghan sits by a small lagoon on the southern shores of the Bahr al-Yeshm, the Jade Sea. Villagers here fish for tuna, sardines, bonito and shark.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B1_1}Ab Comer
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B1_1}Ab Comer sits on the steep pass cut by the upper Trand river that climbs the Uchalion plateau. The tribes of this region grow grapes on the hillsides, used to make a white wine popular with the imperial and Vlandian aristocracies.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B1_2}Inveth
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B5_4}Inveth sits where the rivers Trand and Etir come tumbling out of the Uchalion massif, join together, and flow into the plains of central Vlandia. The surrounding hillsides support the growing of wheat.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B2_1}Llanoc Hen
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B2_1}Llanoc Hen sits in a ridge in the heights of the Uchalion massif. The villagers, known as skilled pig-farmers, look down two passes, the western one leading up from Vlandian lands and the eastern one leading up from the Empire.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B2_2}Cantrec
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B2_2}Cantrec sits in the rocky Glen of Balasog that climbs up from the imperial lands into the plateau of the Uchafion. The lands is not especially fertile here, but pigs thrive in the bush and shrubland of the heights.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B3_1}Druimmor
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B3_1}Druimmor sits in the Morcomb, a rift valley that divides the Uchalion plateau from the mountains of the Ebor peninsula. Miners here have found silver in clefts in the hillsides.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B3_2}Tor Melina
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B3_4}Tor Melina sits in a marshy basin in the dark forested hills of the northwestern Uchalion massif. Villagers take clay from the damp soil for sale to the potters of nearby towns.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B4_1}Pendraic
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B4_1}Pendraic sits on the steep northern slope of the Uchalion, facing the Bay of Varcheg. It is a land of cold winds and constant low-level warfare, cris-crossed by Vlandian, Battanian and Sturgian raiding parties. The villagers raise hogs here, always listening to the warning horns telling them to drive their herds to hiding spots in the hills.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B4_2}Lindorn
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B2_5}Lindorn sits on the green hills north and west of Llyn Tywal, the dark lake. The surrounding farmlands are sown with wheat and barley.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B5_1}Rhemtoil
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B5_1}Rhemtoil lies beneath a cleft in the eastern escarpment of the Uchalion plateau, near the source of the river Miron, which the Battanians call the Myr. This is among the most fertile of the Battanian lands, and produces a fine crop of wheat.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B5_2}Claig Ban
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B5_2}Claig Ban lies at the foot of a steep cleft that climbs the Uchalion massif. The villagers here gather clay from the nearby Myr river for sale to the potters of the Battanian towns.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B6_1}Flintolg
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B6_1}Flintolg sits on a high crest on the eastern side of the Uchalion massif. The soil is poor but the woods grow thick here, making this the source of much of the timber used in the Battanian lands.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B6_2}Glintor
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B6_2}Glintor sits overlooking the rapids of the Fiur river, where the waters of Llyn Tywal descend to enter the Bay of Varcheg. Horses are raised on the downs, much prized by both raiders and traders from the Sturgian lands to the north.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B7_1}Aster
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B7_1}Aster sits in a shallow valley between the hills of the northeastern Uchalion and the Rock of Glanys. The people of this region have the reputation of being more focused on trade than warfare, and tribal elders have encouraged the planting of vineyards to produce a particularly strong vintage of wine.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B7_2}Imlagh
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B2_4}Imlagh lies on rolling downs in the middle of the Uchalion massif. The village specializes in white grapes for the making of the sweet Battanian wines.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B8_1}Uthelaim
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B8_1}Uthelaim sits on the eastern frontiers of the Battanian lands on a ridge overlooking a tributary of the Myr. The people of these parts are foresters, felling the oak, yew and pine of the woods for sale to builders and shipwrights.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B8_2}Seordas
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B4_5}Seordas sits in the lowlands at the eastern edge of the Battanian lands, at the foot of the Uchalion escarpment. The nearby fortress of Uthelaim shields the district's exposed farms from Sturgian raiders coming from the east.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_B1}Marunath
Settlement.text: {=Jm2uZiwV}Marunath, the 'Horse of the Ford,' is nowhere near a river. But Battanian bards love nothing more than an incongruous place-name around which a legend can be woven. In this case the hero Ochlaigan, who was foretold to defeat the seven sons of Glanys in seven duels near seven fords, encountered the last of his enemies here. He slit his horse's throat and crossed over the stream of blood that gushed forth, defeating his last enemy and fulfiling the prophecy.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B1_1}Dalmengus
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B1_1}Dalmengus sits by the side of the Llyn Tywal, the Dark Lake at the center of the Uchalion massif. The flat, well-watered lands here are fertile and well-suited to wheat and barley.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B1_2}Ebereth
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B1_2}Ebereth sits on a saddle, with the lake of Llyn Tywal on one side and the passes of the Cafalcombe on the other. Villagers here grow grapes to make the sweet white wine of the Battanian lands.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B1_3}Beglomuar
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B1_3}Beglomuar sits in a nook of the southern escarpment of the Uchalion massif. There is little to recommend these lands other than the ore deposits in the hills and the bog-iron of the mountain marshes.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B1_4}Ath Cafal
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B1_4}Ath Cafal sits near the head of the Cafalcombe, a steep valley that descends to the imperial lands. Decent clay can be found in the small streams that rush down from the hills on all sides.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_B2}Dunglanys
Settlement.text: {=YERtiSUn}Dunglanys, the 'Rock of Glanys', stands on a high crag overlooking the Llyn Tywal, the pool of darkness at the heart of the Battanian lands. It was named after a ancient queen who, legend has it, married in succession five high kings of Battania, bestowing sovereignty upon them. It is the center of the rituals that underpin Battanian kingship, and though not every Battanian high king has ruled from here, all are eager to hold it.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B2_1}Diantogmail
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B2_1}Diantogmail sits on the edge of Llyn Tywal, the dark lake. There are a half-dozen local legends explaining how the region got its name, which means the 'Flight of the Stoat,' but no two of them match in any particulars. Villagers here gather clay from the lakeside for use by nearby artisans.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B2_2}Glenlithrig
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B2_2}Glenlithrig, the valley of the slippery stream, lies in the highlands of the northern Uchalion. The villagers here are primarily foresters, supplying timber to the nearby fortress-towns of Dunglanys and Car Banseth.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B2_3}Morihig
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B2_3}Morihig sits in a basin in the middle of the Uchalion massif. The region is known for its production of wheat and barley.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_B3}Car Banseth
Settlement.text: {=QD3oaaNK}Car Banseth sits high on the cliffs of Ailta Druin. Staring north on a clear day, across lands that were once Battanian but are now held by the Sturgians and Vlandians, one can see the waters of the Bay of Varcheg. It is said that those who keep faith will one day witness from this high point the ships of the vanished High King Mon, who shall return to deliver his people from their enemies. But today, one is far more likely to see the sails of Nordic adventurers and mercenaries, coming to assist the foreigners in their relentless push into Battanian land.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B3_1}Bog Beth
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B3_1}Bog Beth sits in a low, forested valley in the east of the Uchalion massif. Villagers trap beavers, foxes and other fur-bearing animals in the dark, marshy woods.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B3_2}Geunat Nal
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B3_2}Geunat Nal, the village where Nal left his head, is a fur-trapping village near the site of a duel famous in Battanian legend. The villagers are known for their skill as foresters, helping the nearby cliff-top fortress of Car Banseth to guard the northern approaches to the Battanian heartland from Sturgian and other raiders.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B3_3}Tor Leiad
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B3_3}Tor Leiad, the hill of the full moon, lies beneath a wooded knoll in the northern Battanian lands. Villagers harvest the thick-growing forests of oak, yew and beech. The woods here have been tended carefully by the Battanians for centuries, ensuring that there are always enough trees to harvest and sell for timber.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_B4}Seonon
Settlement.text: {=X3MsaG39}Seonon, sad Seonon, has a history as dark as the waters of the Llyn Tywal. Here Algana the Fair stood atop the tower lamenting the death of her beloved Gorawan, until the spirits of the Otherworld were themselves overcome with sadness and allowed his shade to ascend through the pool for a day and a night to console her. In latter days this land has often been ravaged by Sturgian raiders, and not far from here lies the wood where King Aeril disappeared, clearing the way for the rise of Caladog.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B4_1}Bryn Glas
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B4_1}Bryn Glas sits in a ridge in the eastern escarpment of the Uchalion massif. Villagers raise grapes on the slopes, making a strong, dark red wine highly valued by the Vlandians and the Empire.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B4_2}Andurn
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B4_2}Andurn sits in a cleft in the hills overlooking Llyn Tywal, the dark lake. The villagers of these parts tend the forests, harvesting beech, oak and yew for sale to the towns.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B4_3}Mag Arba
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B4_3}Mag Arba sits on grassy downs overlooking Llyn Tywal, the dark lake. Villagers have planted flax in the boggy dales between the hills.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B4_4}Swenryn
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B4_4}Swenryn overlooks the rocky cataract that holds back the dark waters of the Llyn Tywal, creating the lake in the center of the Uchalion. Horses graze above the rapids and waterfalls.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_B5}Pen Cannoc
Settlement.text: {=4OAz8urz}Pen Cannoc sits on a promontory overlooking the Trand river as it plunges from the Uchalion plateau into the Vlandian lowlands. Legends speak of the water-nymphs who live in the dark pools under the rock, luring travellers and invaders to their deaths, except on those rare occasions when they fall in love with a hero and grant him victory and blessings. Certainly the fisherfolk of this region have learned respect for the perils of the upper Trand, where a small misstep on slippery stone can cast one off a precipice into the waters below.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B5_1}Durn
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B5_1}Durn sits just below the gorges of the upper Trand river. Villagers scrape mud from the pools and bogs alongside the river as it levels out, carting it up the winding paths to the town of Pen Cannoc perched on the cliff above them.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B5_2}Gainseth
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B5_2}Gainseth sits in a dark wooded valley beneath the Rhennod hills on the eastern edge of the Uchalion massif. Villagers collect mud from the marshy ground for sale to the potters of Pen Cannoc.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B5_3}Fenon Etir
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B5_3}Fenon Etir sits on an outcrop overlooking the source of the Etir river, a tributary of the Trand. Below the village the water winds between mounds of slag, the detritus from centuries of mining the iron-rich ores of the nearby hills.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V1_1}Usanc
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_V1_1}Usanc sits by a small bay that flows into the larger Gulf of Charas. This warm southern land supports the growing of olive trees.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V2_1}Hongard
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_V2_1}Hongard sits in the warm wooded lands near the meandering Trand river. This land, rich in wheat and once the heartland of the Empire, is now the center of the Vlandian kingdom.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V2_2}Ferton
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_V2_2}Ferton near a curve of the meandering Trand river, not far from a pass leading seaward over the Biscan Hills. The villagers grow olives on the warm, dry landward side of the hills.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V3_1}Drapand
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_V3_1}Drapand sits near the tip of Cape Fal, a promontory just south of the mouth of the Trand River. The villagers venture out far into the seas to cod-rich banks washed by a cold current from the north.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V3_2}Valanby
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_V3_1}Valanby sits overlooking the Trand estuary. The local landowners raise horses in paddocks reclaimed from the riverside marshes.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V4_1}Ormanfard
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_V4_1}Ormanfard sits by a small, fast-flowing river that runs down from the mountains of the Rhennod to fill the lake known as Ocspool. The hillsides here are terraced for the growing of grapes, which produce a heavy, rich vintage that the wealthy drink mixed with honey and cloves, and the common folk with water.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V5_1}Tirby
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_V5_1}Tirby sits in the cold misty waters that lie off of the Ebor peninsula. The low-lying lands on the northern side of the Ebor are suited to the growing of flax.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V5_2}Sirindac
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_V5_2}Sirindac lies beneath the high ridges of the Ebor peninsula, somewhat sheltered from the bitter winds blowing out of the northwest. Villagers here dig a fine pale clay, rich in mica and feldspar, from the mountain streams.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V6_1}Caleus
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_V6_1}Caleus lies on the misty coastal plain south of the Bay of Varcheg. Villagers speak a mix of the Vlandian, Sturgian and Battanian tongues. They grow flax in the lowlands here.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V6_2}Deriat
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_V6_2}Deriat sits between the Bay of Varcheg and the ridges of the Ebor peninsula. Villagers here trap beaver and mink in the hills and sometimes pursue seals in the waters of the bay.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V7_1}Talivel
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_V7_1}Talivel in the middle of the Trand valley in the heartland of Calradia. Villagers plant olives here on the hillsides.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V7_2}Rodetan
